headline.main: MARINE INTELLIGENCE.; CLEARED. ARRIVED. SAILED. MISCELLANEOUS. MARINE DISASTERS. SPOKEN FOREIGN PORTS. BY CABLE.
MISCELLANEOUS FOREIGN NOTES.; EX-PRESIDENT GRANT IN HOLLAND THE CALENDAR, IN RUSSIA THE IDAHO DISASTER.

docs.snippet: The San Francisco Bulletin of June 10 says: "The bark Athelstane, Capt. Baylep master, from Newcastle, New South Wales, reports that at 8:30 o'clock of the morning of the 29th of May, latitude 89 49' north and longitude 144 2' west, she sighted a ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Bulletin of June 10 says: "The bark Athelstane, Capt. Baylep master, from Newcastle, New South Wales, reports that at 8:30 o'clock of the morning of the 29th of May, latitude 89 49' north and longitude 144 2' west, she sighted a drifting junk, and bore away for her.

headline.main: THE ROTTEN STEAMER METROPOLIS.; REPORT OF THE INSPECTORS' INVESTIGATION -PROSECUTION OF LUNT AND THE NEWBURYPORT SHIP-CARPENTER RECOMMENDED.

byline.original: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times

headline.main: MARINE DISASTERS.; THE SCHOONER ADALINE TOWNSEND SUNK BY THE SCHOONER SOPHIA WILSON--OTHER DISASTERS.

docs.snippet: The Metropolis and the Huron were both wrecked in nearly the same locality. This however, is the only point of resemblanee between the two disasters. The Huron was wrecked because the navigating officer, who doubtless learned seamanship from an An...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Metropolis and the Huron were both wrecked in nearly the same locality. This however, is the only point of resemblanee between the two disasters. The Huron was wrecked because the navigating officer, who doubtless learned seamanship from an Annapolis text-book and not from experience.

headline.main: HOW A WRECKED SHIP WAS FLOATED.

docs.snippet: Below the print a letter received from Capt. Hardy, of the lost schooner Van Name, by George M. Smith, of New-York, and by him sent to a resident  of this city. It is a graphic story of the disaster, and of the sufferings of the survivors before t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Below the print a letter received from Capt. Hardy, of the lost schooner Van Name, by George M. Smith, of New-York, and by him sent to a resident of this city. It is a graphic story of the disaster, and of the sufferings of the survivors before they were rescued. The steward and two passengers children were lost.

headline.main: THE LOSS OF THE C. J. VAN NAME.; THE CAPTAIN TELLS HOW SHE FOUNDERED AT SEA THREE LIVES LOST A TERRIBLE NIGHT PASSED BY THE SURVIVORS, FLOATING ON SCANTLINGS AND SURROUNDED BY SHARKS.

docs.snippet: Captain SPENCE, of the packet ship Northumberland, of MORGAN  WILEY'S line of London packets, gives the following account of the loss of his ship. It was with great difficulty that the lives of all on board were saved....
docs.lead_paragraph: Captain SPENCE, of the packet ship Northumberland, of MORGAN WILEY'S line of London packets, gives the following account of the loss of his ship. It was with great difficulty that the lives of all on board were saved.

headline.main: SEA AND SHIP NEWS.; Loss of the Ship Northumberland.

docs.snippet: THE GREAT RACE ACROSS THE ATLANTIC.-- The Persia, on her last trip, passed the Vanderbilt, enroute to Southampton, on the 31 of August, at 8 A. M. in lat. 42 26' long. 62 56' ? also, passed the Atlantic en route to Liverpool, on the same day, at 9...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE GREAT RACE ACROSS THE ATLANTIC.-- The Persia, on her last trip, passed the Vanderbilt, enroute to Southampton, on the 31 of August, at 8 A. M. in lat. 42 26' long. 62 56' ? also, passed the Atlantic en route to Liverpool, on the same day, at 9 1/2 A.M., in lat 438 18, long. 638 21.
